What are some ways we can enhance our listening skills to fully understand and comprehend what others are communicating to us, rather than focusing on our own responses or biases?

I would start with the thought to truly hope to understand what the other person is saying. Most of us, when listening, are formulating an opinion, either in response—what are we going to say in response? What do I think about this? Or looking for something to disagree with, or a piece to latch onto. We take a little piece and then tune out from what’s being said. Any ability to turn our own filters off, forget about what we think, not be analytical at all, and only listen with the idea of truly understanding what the person is communicating.

How do you feel about the 17 minutes of silence utilized before the final track of Nirvana's Nevermind album, considering how it deviates from conventional music producing?

I think it’s cool. Anything that breaks the norm is interesting. It forces the listener to engage in the music in a different way. The purpose of something like that is to feel like the album’s over, and you’re going about your business, and you forget you’re even listening to it. Then you’re surprised by this thing that happens. It forces you to pay attention in a way that doesn’t come so naturally. It essentially tricks the audience into forgetting that they were listening to music.

I understand that Cage's philosophy extends beyond just music, but do you adhere to any particular aspect of it in your work?

Absolutely! There is a particular story from Cage's book, I believe it called Silence, that deeply resonated with me. It's about when he was driving to a public Q&A. On the way, he prepared five answers that he planned to use randomly for any questions he might be asked. This randomness, this willingness to let things happen naturally, really struck me as an amazing way to approach not just music, but life.
So, you'd say that Cage's philosophy has informed the way you approach your art, even as you came into your own in a different time period?

Definitely. Cage's philosophy has been incredibly impactful. The story I read in his book, Silence, where he was preparing for a Q&A exemplifies his profoundness. He prepared five answers beforehand and planned to randomly distribute them, regardless of the question asked. This evidenced a beautiful blend of elements of chance and control that he weaves into his music and his general approach to life. This really spoke to me and I try to incorporate similar principles into my art.

Now, as you know, the New York avant-garde of the ’50s and ’60s was greatly influenced by John Cage. You’re coming a bit later, coming of age in the ’80s. Is that an influence on you as well? And if so, what did you take from Cage?

One of the greatest things I can remember reading was a story in Cage’s book. I think it’s called Silence. He tells a story where he’s driving. He’s on his way to do a Q&A. He was going over the five answers that he prepared that he would use randomly for whatever questions were asked. I just thought that was beautifully Cageian. It was beautiful that his philosophy extended past his music to a way of being in the world. I really appreciated that.

Do you believe that the music industry has evolved over the years, especially in terms of artist compensation?

Certainly. It's interesting to look back at the likes of The Beatles, who were only earning several pennies per album sold. However, as artists started gaining more leverage, they were able to negotiate better deals. This progression can be best seen in Michael Jackson's case; he was earning approximately $2 per album, which was significantly higher than his contemporaries.
Are the music artists of today in a better position financially as compared to those of the past?

It seems to be the case. We've come a long way since the days when artists were paid just a few pennies per album. Today, given proper leverage and negotiation power, they can make much more, as Michael Jackson did, earning around $2 per album sold.
Do you think the widespread advent of streaming threatens the economic viability of a successful ecosystem for musical production and sale?

I think it can be. I don’t think it is yet. If you look at the history of recorded music, at the time that the Beatles were making albums, I think they were paid several pennies per album sold. Then over time, the artists got more leverage and were able to negotiate better deals. I think it finally culminated in the old music business with Michael Jackson, who was getting maybe $2 per album that was sold, which was much more than everybody else. In the early days of singles, people were paid very little.
